text: mark let's talk about this Libya
operation which seems in some sense to
be the worst kind of situation for a
president trying to apply military force
for a purpose that may look discreet and
limited at the beginning but it's hard
to control as time goes on how do you
see that well that was precisely why the
administration was so reluctant to be
dragged into this I mean if you recall
President Obama and even more vocally
his Secretary of Defense Bob gates were
very resistant to this and gate sworn
that you know let's call a spade a spade
where was the phrase he used a no-fly
zone is never as surgical and operation
as you think it's going to be if Qaddafi
doesn't fall as a result of this how
long are they willing to go on with it
and what forms of escalation are they
willing to contemplate very very tough
it's very tough and you can actually see
a paradox already in the
administration's position on Qaddafi
himself President Obama has called for
Qaddafi to step down Secretary Clinton
has also called for him to step down yet
Admiral Mullen over the weekend
suggested that there might be an outcome
where Qaddafi would remain in power are
you willing to live with a Libya that's
in effect split in two and a stalemate
and that's the prospect that they're
facing now it seems to me that one of
the other problems that the
administration faces at a time when
there's so much unrest across the Middle
East is defining okay you're intervening
in Libya what about Bahrain what about
Yemen this question of when you
intervene and when you don't is
obviously one of the thorniest ones that
every American president faces Egypt was
an optimal outcome yeah Egypt was an
unusual case because you had a military
a that had very deep ties to the United
States and the be played a very
responsible role in the society in
Qaddafi and Libya you have neither how
much of a headache is this likely to be
for a president who wants to head into
his reelection campaign talking about
domestic issues in the economy
considerable obviously the White House
has said we're not going to allow
upheaval in the Arab world to deflect us
from our agenda now though that you have
a shooting war underway in Libya it's
going to be tougher and tougher for him
not to
allow foreign policy and the upheaval in
the Arab world to overwhelm his schedule
and indeed it's already overshadowing
his trip to Latin America were at every
stop rather than being asked about trade
issues he's asked about what's going on
in the Middle East so it will be a
bigger and bigger distraction for him
going forward headaches aren't going
away thanks more
you
